content: It depends on the specific condition that the patient has. For conditions that affect both the heart and lungs, such as pulmonary hypertension or congestive heart failure, both a cardiologist and a pulmonologist may be involved in the patient's care. They may work together as a team to manage the patient's symptoms, recommend appropriate medication or treatment, and monitor the patient's progress over time. However, if the condition is primarily related to the heart, such as a heart attack or a heart valve disease, a cardiologist is likely to be the main specialist involved in the patient's care. On the other hand, if the condition is primarily related to the lungs, such as COPD or asthma, a pulmonologist would be the main specialist involved in the patient's care. In some cases, a patient may need to see both a cardiologist and a pulmonologist concurrently for their heart and lung problems to be properly managed. It's always best to consult with your primary care physician to determine which specialist you need to see for your specific health condition.
